name: Netherlands
takeaway: The Netherlands is by tradition a China-hawk country in terms of diplomacy, domestic politics and social attitudes. There are hardly any leading politicians who avoid criticizing the PRC’s human rights record. Mass media is also largely critical with the regime in Beijing, even those journalists who have been invited on tours in the PRC.
Chinese investments do exist in critical infrastructure, such as sea ports, but their growth and influence are blocked as a results of measures taken at the EU level.

PRC influence in Technology used to be substantial, but it has diminished recently. Exports of sensitive technology made in Netherlands, for instance industrial equipment for advanced chip making, have been blocked by decision of the government. Telecom equipment supplied by PRC-related entities in the past will be provided from different sources.

Academia was a strong lever of influence in the past, as significant university research programs existed in technology, plus cultural connections through the Confucius institutes. However a solid tradition of transparency and media scrutiny have mitigated the risks of undue influence, as the image of PRC has deteriorated globally.
description-1: In 2023, Netherlands had a GDP per capita of US$62,537 and a total population of 18.02 million people.
description-2: Netherlands established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1972. Netherlands was ranked 4th in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 97/100.

Media.evidence: The website of the WCM lists three publications that function in the Netherlands, though it is difficult to evaluate if they are still functional at this point. Therefore, the indicator deserves a "Few" and "Insignificant" rating.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: No indication of such a phenomenon was found.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: The entries that I have found featured journalists who were invited to the PRC a few years ago, but they always disclosed the funding and were somewhat critical of the PRC government in what they wrote.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: Reports studying the level of PRC media influence in the Netherlands shows there is no official PRC state media in the country or on youtube in the national language. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "No" rating.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: Direct PRC influence on media ownership is not mentioned in thinktank reporting. There are some allusions to Chinese language media existing and toeing the line of the PRC, but these are considered few and unimportant. Therefore, the indicator deserves the "Few" and "Insignifican" rating.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: No indication of such a phenomenon was found in recent years.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: The PRC Ambassador wrote a COVID-related open letter that was published in the Dutch media as advertisement, which was presented as unusual, but there is systemic evidence that this would be a strategic approach of the PRC in the Netherlands. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Few" and "Insignificant" rating.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: No cases of Dutch journalists in the Netherlands being exposed to pressure from the PRC government, but at least one clear and notorious case of a Dutch journalist assaulted during the Beijing Olympics in 2022, within the PRC. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Yes" rating.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: Seems highly unlikely, seeing the general climate of reluctance in the Netherlands.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: The Dutch Parliament voted a motion to call the PRC's treatment of Uygurs as genocide; while there were MPs who voted against the motion, they were all critical of the PRC. It is unlikely there are any cases of relevant political figures in the Netherlands who would deny the existence of human rights abuses in the PRC.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: There seem to be a number of universities with some sort of technical research partnership with PRC-connected entities, especially in the realm of new technology. The media is heavily scrutinizing these partnerships, though, which greatly reduces their potential to be significant in exerting influence.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: There seem to be a number of Confucius Institutes that are active in the Netherlands and have been greatly investigated by the local media in recent years. The Minister of Education has asked all universities to drop their connections with Confucius Institutes and only Leiden university has done so until now.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: There seems to be an important contingent of Confucius Institutes in the Netherlands, which mediate Chinese language education classes (and course materials) though especially at the University level. In addition, the Dutch ministers of Education have issued repeated statements discouraging cooperation with these institutes, especially starting 2021. It is unclear at this point if alternative solutions have been identified. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Yes" response.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: There seem to be a few research centers in Italy which are affiliated or belong to PRC networks/associations, though it is highly unlikely that their activity is directly controlled by PRC political interests. Therefore, this indicator deserves an "Insignificant" rating.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: While some financial benefits from PRC-connected entities or institutions still exist, Dutch universities are increasingly dropping such cooperation or financial benefits due to concerns about required impartiality and media scrutiny. It is expected that the trend will further continue.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: There are some cases that have been reported, and Dutch civil society has already started investigating how far this participation goes and if it generates downstream negative consequences. It is somewhat limited and draws heavy focus. Therefore, this indicator deservers a "Few" and an "Insignificant" rating.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: Some news of such activities exists, but it is already dated and was conducted through the Confucius Institute, apparently. Therefore, the indicator deserves a ”Few and Insignificant” rating.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: There have been accusations in this direction, but they have generally been resisted well by the academic staff and students and brought to public debate. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "More than a few" and "Insignificant" rating.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: There are some cases that have been reported, the most famous of which being the development of language and culture classes at Groningen University in cooperation with the Confucius Institute, who forced the professor to sign a contract demanding she would not criticize the PRC. The University subsequently cancelled the cooperation and the media and civil society increased their scrutiny over similar events in the future. More recently, the Dutch Minister of Education requested schools and universities in the Netherlands stop cooperation with Confucius Institutes. It is unclear to what extent this recommendation was followed, though.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: There is an important pattern of political leaders especially signing agreements with the PRC government and agencies. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "More than a few" rating. Concurrently, most of these political leaders are at most secondary leaders in their own political organizations, with little influence. Further, starting with 2022, there seems to be a fair consensus among political parties (especially right-wing parties) regarding prudence in Italy's relationship with the PRC. Therefore, this indicator deserves an "Insignificant" rating.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Many cities have such ties with municipalities in the PRC. Government has been inspecting these ties closely in recent years, so that their risks are significantly muted. Therefore, the indicator deserves a More than a Few and Insignificant rating.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon and it generally seems unlikely at this point.

Domestic Politics.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.

Domestic Politics.evidence: There is no indication of such events ever occurring and it is highly unlikely given the relatively high capacity and institutional independence of the Dutch government. A special case of this is the PRC funded informal police stations in the Netherlands, which have been heavily criticized by the government and media.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Campaign donations are transparent and extremely scrutinized in the Netherlands. No information was found about such a phenomenon.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: There is an investigative report presenting a Chinese-Dutch entrepreneur who was a political candidate for the Dutch Christian Democratic Party. The individual was connected with the PRC and the UFWD, but he was ultimately unsucessful in his parliamentary bid.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: There are no systemic examples of such a behavior and the closest is the case of a Dutch Ambassador to the PRC who was suspended after news of an affair with a local employee in 2016.

Economy.evidence: The PRC owns some important stakes in port infrastructure in the Netherlands, though the shares seem to be far from offering the PRC substantial control. Overall, there is significant PRC ownership in companies operating in the Netherlands, though it is exposed to significant oversight from the European Commission and the Dutch government, with further investment being blocked.

Economy.evidence: The Netherlands is a member, therefore this Indicator deserves a "Yes" response. As a mitigating factor, it is unclear to what extent the Netherlands uses the AIIB's services or is in any way influenced by this membership.

Economy.evidence: The meaning of major businesses is debatable, but there seems to be no mention of companies of note that are members in these Commercial associations. The only identifiable exception is the Netherlands Council for Trade Promotion, which is a BRICA member, though it is by no means a major business or even an active agent in the country.

Economy.evidence: While there is no news of existing economic coercion actions initiated by the PRC against the Netherlands, a recent Dutch decision will restrict semi-conductor tech to the PRC (in a joint effort with the US and Japan). It is assumed that this decision may generate some sort of economic reaction from the PRC, though none is forthcoming.

Technology.evidence: It is unclear from the information available if China Telecom only has an office in the Netherlands, which offers international services and tax representation or actually offers individual telefon services. Most likely, it seems individual services are not provided in the Netherlands.

Technology.evidence: As in many other EU countries, the Netherlands has telecom providers that had previously relied heavily on Huawei equipment, particularly because of its more accessible pricing, though the Dutch government has been pressuring these providers to not renew these agreements with PRC related enterprises because of security reasons.

Technology.evidence: Media investigations have uncovered a series of PRC-connected entities which seem to be vendors of tech-related equipment or services to the government, though there is a clear backlash from the government, attempting to undo the situation. It is unclear at this point if any such company continues to function, but it is most likely that oversight will be increased in future years.

Law Enforcement.evidence: The Netherlands had an extradition treaty with Hong Kong, but this was suspended in 2021.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Law Enforcement.evidence: It seems highly unlikely that the Dutch Parliament would deem the PRC's of Uygurs to be genocide and then cooperate on combatting terrorism.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Law Enforcement.evidence: The Netherlands is registering an increased presence of organized crime, especially "transit crime", due to its status as point of entry for trade in the EU. In this context, there are mentions of Triad activity in the Netherlands, though it is by no means the most heavy such presence.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Law Enforcement.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.

Law Enforcement.evidence: There is no indication of such events ever occurring and it is highly unlikely given the relatively high capacity and institutional independence of the Dutch government. A special case of this is the PRC funded informal police stations in the Netherlands, which have been heavily criticized by the government and media.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Law Enforcement.evidence: While the Triad is certainly present in the Netherlands (especially in the port areas), there is little evidence that they engage in active repression against even the local Chinese speaking population, as local authorities are heavily invested in rooting them out. It is highly unlikely that organized crime is targeting individuals based on political reasons.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Law Enforcement.evidence: The PRC has been accused by the Dutch secret service of being responsible for multiple cyber-attacks on the country within recent years. This is potentially one of the reasons that secret service have deemed the PRC to be the greatest threat to Dutch economic security in 2022.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Law Enforcement.evidence: There have been news reports pointing to the existence of unofficial PRC police stations in the Netherlands, which are used to control the local Chinese-speaking population. At least 2 such police stations were discussed in 2022, which lead to a significant reaction by the Dutch government to investigate this. As in other places, the PRC Embassy presented these police stations as volunteer-based local civil society organizations. I am unsure of how to grade this finding, though, as it is clear that the government is cracking down on this phenomena.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Law Enforcement.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Law Enforcement.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Law Enforcement.evidence: There are some older reports of the Netherlands' law enforcement having used PRC companies to supply video equipment. Though it is unlikely this practice was perpetuated after the Dutch secret service took a critical position on PRC threat, there are no discernible sources that certify new suppliers of video or internet surveillance systems. Therefore, the indicator deserves a "Yes" rating.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.
